The cause of death from coronavirus pneumonia mainly included the following three categories 52 based on the currently available clinical study report:
(1) Multiple organ failure: concurrent respiratory failure, circulatory failure, and renal failure, 54 particularly in elderly patients with underlying diseases.
(2) Sudden cardiac arrest: sudden cardiac arrest although having stable vital signs (regardless of 56 organ function support); patient died after resuscitation failure.

(3) Sudden exacerbation of condition: sudden exacerbation of symptoms during stable condition 58 or improvement of condition, including rapid deterioration of respiratory function, sudden 59 cardiac dysfunction, sudden circulatory failure, leading to cardiac arrest and death. should be taken as much as possible as to prevent the occurrence of cardiac arrest.
(2) Recognition of other critical indicators for cardiac arrest as early as possible, e.g., septic 109 shock, renal failure, internal environment disturbance, fluid overload.

FIGREF2.text: Mortality of novel coronavirus pneumonia and current causes of death 35 *Manuscript Click here to view linked References Among the 6 coronaviruses that have infected humans in the past 20 years, the coronavirus 36 causing explosive and highly infectious diseases with high morbidity and mortality include 37 SARS virus (SARS-CoV) in 2003, which infected 8,096 patients, caused the death of 774 38 patients, and had the mortality of 9.6% and infection rate of 21.07% in health care personnel 39 (HCP); Middle East Respiratory Syndrome virus (MERS-CoV) in 2012-2015, which infected 40 2,374 patients, caused the death of 837 patients, and had the mortality of 34.7% and infection 41 rate of 19-21% in HCP; and the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pneumonia that started in 42 Wuhan, China, in December 2019 and is considered as the seventh coronavirus that infects 43 humans. In accordance with the latest epidemiological and clinical study reports, the number of 44 patients infected and dead in China were 74,576 and 2,118 by February 20, 2020 respectively, 45 indicating a mortality rate of 2.3%-2.5% and the infection rate (on-duty and off-duty infection) 46 was 3.8-4.0% in HCP. Although the mortality of novel coronavirus pneumonia was not as high as 47 that of SARS and MERS, the base of infected patients and cumulative number of dead patients 48 were high; in human coronavirus infection series, the number of patients infected with novel 49 coronavirus pneumonia and cumulative number of dead patients have been ranked in the 50 high-order section [2-10] .

FIGREF3.text: Prediction, prevention, and early warning of cardiac arrest in patients with novel coronavirus 61 pneumonia 62 2.1 On the basis of the above three main causes of deaths from novel coronavirus pneumonia, 63 the capability of Modern Critical Medicine has been mainly relied on for the first category of 64 death in elderly patients with underlying disease and concurrent multiple organ failure in order prevent or reduce the occurrence of multiple organ failure as much as possible and to use various 66 organ function support technologies after the occurrence. Targeted prediction, prevention, and J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f early warning measures were particularly needed to prevent the pathophysiological abnormalities 68 of peri-arrest state, and early recognition and intervention were needed to reduce the incidence 69 of cardiac arrest and to enable return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) and survival discharge 70 rate after the occurrence for the second and third categories of cause of death. 71 Early warning and early correction of the pathophysiological abnormalities in the peri-arrest 72 state or pathophysiological abnormalities in the pre-arrest state can play an important role in the 73 prevention and cardiopulmonary resuscitation of cardiac arrest; once cardiac arrest occurred, 74 ROSC and the survival discharge rate were low despite conducting high-quality 75 cardiopulmonary resuscitation. This was also a challenge faced by international cardiopulmonary 76 resuscitation medical community. The success rate of cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the 77 avoidance of infection in health care personnel were also challenges while conducting 78 cardiopulmonary resuscitation by the health care personnel wearing three-level protective 79 clothing under limited space, limited medical staff to patient ratio, and specific environment for 80 cardiac arrest in patients with explosive and highly infectious diseases, such as novel coronavirus 81 pneumonia. 82 2.2 Early warning of the causes of cardiac arrest in patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia. 83 In case of no outbreak of epidemic situation, the cause of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) 84 was 70%-80% cardiogenic, particularly in patients with acute myocardial infarction; the main 85 causes of in-hospital cardiac arrest (IHCA) were hypoxemia/respiratory failure, shock and 86 cardiac causes. Except multiple organ failure, the cases of sudden cardiac arrest in in-patients 87 who died due to novel coronavirus pneumonia were associated with the following factors: (1) 88 sudden exacerbation of condition, particularly impaired lung oxygenation leading to respiratory 89 failure and inadequate time for tracheal intubation, invasive respiratory support or ineffective 90 respiratory support; (2) sudden exacerbation of myocardial injury resulting from various reasons, 91 including viral myocarditis and anoxia, leading to acute cardiac failure and serious arrhythmia; 92 (3) sepsis and cardiogenic shock. Therefore, the following prediction, prevention and early 93 warning measures for cardiac arrest have been proposed [11-13] : 94 High attention to respiratory function, including pulmonary CT image, respiratory rate, pulse 95 oxygen and blood gas analysis; recognition of lung injury and respiratory failure and prevention 96 of exacerbation of injury as early as possible; once lung injury, decreased PaO2/FiO2, and 97 respiratory failure occurred, the possibility of cardiac arrest should be considered as a warning, 98 and oxygen therapy at all levels should be started immediately, including noninvasive ventilation, 99 invasive ventilation, correction of respiratory failure; and priority strategy of tracheal intubation J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f and invasive mechanical ventilation should be used to prevent the occurrence of cardiac arrest. 101 (1) Recognition of myocardial injury as early as possible, including monitoring of myocardial 102 enzyme, cardiac function and arrhythmia; prevention of acute heart failure and malignant 103 arrhythmia, attention paid to avoid use of drugs that may aggravate or affect cardiac function 104 and arrhythmia; once pathophysiological abnormalities in the pre-arrest state occurred, such 105 as acute heart failure, serious arrhythmia and shock, the possibility of cardiac arrest should 106 be considered as warning, and various corrective and supportive measures for critical illness 107

FIGREF4.text: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation strategy for cardiac arrest in novel coronavirus 111 pneumonia 112 Relative to the cardiopulmonary resuscitation procedure for OHCA , there were corresponding 113 strategies and procedures for cardiopulmonary resuscitation for the different causes of cardiac 114 arrest in patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia and resuscitation environment.

FIGREF5.text: resuscitation strategy for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) 116 Out-of-hospital environment included household, work unit, social public area, and other 117 non-medical area; in such places, the basic life support CPR is always provided by non-medical 118 staff, which primarily includes chest compression, mouth-to-mouth ventilation and defibrillation 119 with Automated External Defibrillator (AED); mouth-to-mouth ventilation is not suitable as 120 patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia are highly contagious; therefore, the following 121 measures are recommended [14-17] : Chest compression + defibrillation with AED (when necessary) Chest compression + active abdominal compression-decompression instrument (device) + 124 AED (when necessary) 125 Personnel specially trained in active abdominal compression-decompression instrument (device) 126 can use this device to establish abdominal respiration to replace chest respiration, until the arrival 127 of healthcare professionals.

FIGREF6.text: resuscitation strategy for in-hospital cardiac arrest 135 Cardiac arrest in patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia mostly occurred in medical 136 institutions and mainly occurred in severe or critically ill patients in isolation ward or ICU; given 137 the pathophysiological abnormalities in the peri-arrest state in patients with novel coronavirus 138 pneumonia, high infectivity of the disease, high-concentration pathogen environment, 139 nonprofessional medical worker to patient ratio and the features of protective measures for health 140 care personnel, the cardiopulmonary resuscitation strategy and procedure for in-patient cardiac 141 arrest in patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia are recommended as below: 142 The following principles and strategies are recommended for cardiopulmonary resuscitation 143 technique and procedures [18-22] : Protective measures for Class A infectious diseases: the highest level of protective measures 145 against infectious diseases were taken for resuscitation personnel (three-level protection, 146 including full-face protection for respiration).

FIGREF7.text: Emergent endotracheal intubation: endotracheal intubation of the patients was performed 148 under the guidance of fibrobronchoscope or visual laryngoscope and under sedative state. Chest compression : mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation could be used to replace 150 manual chest compression, particularly in cases of insufficient resuscitation personnel and 151 physical collapse, in order to avoid decreased quality of chest compression and increased 152 infection chances induced by accidental entry of pathogenic sweat into the conjunctiva and 153 nasal-oral mucosa of the cardiopulmonary resuscitation provider due to sweating from 154 fatigue. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation for 30 minutes: in accordance with the cause of cardiac arrest 156 as well as the mechanism of the disease injury and number of cardiopulmonary resuscitation 157 provider, in combination with ethical factors, discontinuation of cardiopulmonary 158 resuscitation could be considered after cardiopulmonary resuscitation for more than 30 min 159 with no ROSC (no any vital sign present during cardiopulmonary resuscitation; except under 160 the support of ECMO and extracorporeal circulation) (see the algorithm for warning and 161 cardiopulmonary resuscitation for cardiac arrest in patients with novel coronavirus J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f pneumonia
